snippet: Certain disease-causing variant genes became more common in African-Americans after their ancestors reached American shores, scientists report.
abstract: Study published in journal Genome Research finds that certain disease-causing variant genes became more common in African-Americans after their ancestors reached America, while others, such as the gene for sickle cell hemoglobin, have become less common; researchers, led by Li Jin of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, suggest certain genes may have proliferated because they conferred secondary, offsetting benefits.
lead_paragraph: Certain disease-causing variant genes became more common in African-Americans after their ancestors reached American shores, scientists report.

headline.seo: Genome Research Points to Adaptation Among Early African-Americans
headline.main: Genome Study Points to Adaptation in Early African-Americans
headline.print_headline: Genome Study Points to Adaptation in Early African-Americans
